Award.AwardTitle: SHB: Type I (EXP): Context-aware Ubiquitous Human Health Monitoring

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops a ubiquitous human health monitoring system that collects not only vital signs, but also daily activities and environmental context of a human subject in an everyday life setting. From these collected data, higher level knowledge, such as behavioral and vital sign anomalies, is extracted to assist health evaluation, medical diagnosis/prognosis or healthcare delivery. The research team first develops a low-cost and power-aware wearable Smart Health Monitoring (SmartMon) system, which is integrated into human clothing with minimized obtrusiveness to the wearer. The research team then employs a minimalist approach to understand human?s daily activities and environmental context using the data collected by the SmartMon system. The research team further develops adaptive and intelligent signal processing algorithms to detect anomalies in human daily activities and vital signs for health assessment applications.

This research can significantly improve the ubiquitousness, accuracy, and reliability of wearable human health monitoring. The technologies developed in this project have many different applications, from improving quality of life for elderly people to enhancing capability of first responders during emergency responses. Through the involvement of female, minority (Native American) students, this project prepares a more diversified workforce in the area of biomedical engineering for the State of Oklahoma and the nation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
By integrating embedded computing, computational intelligence and functional apparel design, this project facilitates the knowledge discovery about a human subject for healthcare purposes. It contributes to transforming the healthcare from reactive and hospital-centered to preventive, proactive, evidence-based, person-centered, with a focus on wellbeing rather than disease.

The research findings of this project are:

1)This work developed a theoretical framework to understand human’s daily activity and environmental context with a minimum infrastructure support and a minimum number of motion sensors, which makes ubiquitous health monitoring possible and practical.

2) This work developed a low-cost, power-aware SmartMon system that is tightly integrated into the human clothing, which minimizes the obtrusiveness to the wearer.

3)This work developed adaptive, intelligent signal processing algorithms to detect anomalies in daily activities and vital signs, which makes remote health assessment practical and efficient.

The broader impacts of this project are:

1)This project has great impacts to the healthcare industry and health research community. Due to the increased ubiquitousness, accuracy and lifetime of data collection and processing, the developed SmartMon system has the potential to not only improve existing healthcare practices, but also create new healthcare services and research frontiers. When used by physicians to monitor their patients, or elderly, this monitoring system can greatly improve the accuracy of human health assessment and medical diagnosis in an everyday life setting. Through prevention and early detection of disease or optimal maintenance of chronic conditions, this monitoring system will augment existing healthcare systems. As the baby boomers step into their retirement age, such a smart health monitoring system will enable physicians to have a better understanding of the living behavior of elderly and help improve their quality of life. Physical rehabilitation is another important area this new monitoring system can be used in, where physicians can assess how their patients are recovering after a stroke and find out what is the best rehabilitation plan for a particular patient. This will make possible highly adaptive and customized physical rehabilitation.

2) The impact of this SmartMon system is not limited to the healthcare community. This monitoring system can be used to study the athletic training where the effectiveness of training program can be evaluated and correlated with an athlete’s vital signs, body orientation, range of motion (ROM), etc. This monitoring system will also have great potential for first responder health monitoring during emergency responses, which can greatly reduce the risk and improve the efficiency of operations. During this project we reached out to the local community and minority groups. We demonstrated our research projects to many local students and their parents through various recruitment and outreach events.

3) Through the rigorous training and practice in embedded computing, wireless communication, biomedical engineering and cloud computing, the graduate students and undergraduate students involved in this project have obtained precious knowledge and experience that prepare them for a future career in areas that are very promising.
